column7: Location (10 digit grid ref or latitude/longitude). Please give as accurate a location as possible
column8: Description of bird location (e.g. in stubble field to NW of junction between Lamsey Lane and A149)
column9: Enter colour combination. If you are reporting multiple yellow flag + orange ring sightings from the same location (e.g. the same flock), then you can enter your flags as: LA = YFN 5U /  2X / 6X / 7U, Orange; etc
column10: Comments. Please add any extra information about the bird's behaviour (e.g. foraging, roosting, etc), whether it was in a flock with other Curlew or wader species and the flock size, etc. Any information is useful, so be as descriptive as you can.
column11: Do you have photographs or videos of the bird?
column12: Email address (only if you are happy to be contacted about the sighting, your photos / videos, or would like to receive information about the individual)
column13: I have read and agreed to the terms given in the BTO's privacy policy

column7: 996 825 grid ref on my OS explorer map 125 . Exmouth Exe Estuary
column8: . 100 yards into Exe Estuary / Exmouth Nature Reserve at low tide feeding in reeds and on mud flat sands . Observed from cycle track through binos. Flag on left leg . I thought red ring . Yellow ring on other leg .
column9: LA . Flag on left leg. Red ring above it  . Yellow ring right leg . I didnt fully understand your tag combinations
column10: Looked healthy and  younger , not as tall than two others untagged close by. Was not feeding with them but did interact and run around with one briefly. Low tide and close to shore . Was very busy and spent a lot of time literally running around while others were just feeding and wandering . I picked up onit as it was dashing around then I notice flag. It then found reeds and grasses and disappeared inside and could see it foraging constantly  . The photo I have is the area it is in .it's in the photo but I can't zoom on phone camera .

column10: Bird was feeding on mud at low tide. It was loosely associated with 13 other Curlew. On one occasion, one of the other unringed Curlews acted aggressively towards the ringed bird and drove it away from a small sub-group of 5 Curlews. Bird was seen between 14.30 and 14.40 hours through a telescope.

column10: In a flock of 182 Curlew (including 17 WWRG-flagged birds as well as one other Headstarted bird 5U). The flock was feeding and roosting. High tide was at 04:54. The whole flock flew off west towards the beach at 10:10.

column8: I photographed the Curlew on the 22nd May 2023. It was also in the same field a day later on the 23rd but I did not photograph it. The Curlew was alone on both days feeding and i have not seen the Curlew since.
column9: 6H
column10: Curlew do still breed in this area and in fact further up the road from the photos i was photographing a pair of Hobby and a Buzzard came over and a pair of Curlew came up from the ground and harassed the Buzzard until it was off the Curlew territory. A sure sign of breeding Curlew with young. It was not until i put the photos on my computer that i noticed the Curlew was ringed so never paid any attention to look for a leg ring when the Buzzard came over.

column10: The Curlew was initially on the edge of the tide line on the incoming tide roosting on the leg with the flag. It then flew towards us (with its flag leg curled up!), roosted on one leg again then flew again towards us so it was then N of us. Eventually it began to walk and we were able to read the flag. It was amongst a flock of 160 Curlew and was seen to be poking around in a lump of seaweed. There were several WWRG marked birds in the vicinity and headstarted YJ had been seen earlier.

column8: Photographed from the "Knots' Landing" hide at the southern end of Pit 4 at Snettisham RSPB
column9:
LA = Yellow flag engraved YC, Orange
RA = Yellow
column10: This was one of two Curlews that flew in at about 09.30am and landed on the island immediately outside the hide.  The island was occupied a mixed gathering of several hundred shorebirds, mostly Black-tailed Godwits and Knot.  For a short while the Curlew appeared to be seeking food in vegetation close to where it had landed but soon both birds attached themselves to the edge of the flock and settled to roost. The other Curlew was unringed.
